title: 10 best cutlery sets that make any meal a special occasion
text:
Good cutlery can turn a mid-week meal into an occasion, which is why it’s always worth investing in a decent set of knives, forks and spoons – we deserve to feel like we’re eating at a fancy restaurant even when it’s takeaway Tuesday.

Whether you’re after an everyday set, or something special to impress the guests at dinner parties, shiny matching utensils will add a smart finish to your perfectly laid out table, and you don’t have to be fully au fait with Debrett’s guide on table settings to take pride in that.

There’s a wealth of beautifully designed table tools out there, and excitingly, we’ve seen a move away from the traditional stainless steel, into bright golds and coppers, matte blacks and even iridescent cutlery, bringing all the colours of the rainbow to our contemporary table setting.

When choosing a cutlery set for your kitchen drawer, look for evenly weighted utensils for comfort and ergonomics of hand (you’ll eat better with these, making your manners-obsessed granny proud).

You’ll find that the heavier the cutlery the better the quality – as a general rule. And while traditional stainless steel scrubs up well you may find some of the more creative and design-led styles are not suited to packing into the dishwasher, so save these for the occasional dinner party and wash later in warm soapy water.

Although you can purchase knives, forks and spoons individually, or less commonly, in single place settings, our top cutlery picks are in sets of at least 16, which will cater for four people around the table. But it’s wise to go bigger on numbers for those times the extended family gather for a Sunday roast – you don’t want to get caught out with mismatching cutlery.

You can trust our independent reviews. We may earn commission from some of the retailers, but we never allow this to influence selections, which are formed from real-world testing and expert advice. This revenue helps to fund journalism across The Independent.

Dibor luxury gold cutlery set, 24-piece: £92, Dibor

This solid set brought an immediate richness to our table, offsetting our white dinnerware and linen beautifully. Comprising six simple place settings – knife, fork, dessert spoon and teaspoon – the gilded cutlery is both reliably weighty and has a high quality finish. In a bright yellow gold colour that’s classy, not brassy, these elegant utensils manage to make every sitting special, even a hurried bowl of cornflakes. The perfect addition to the Christmas lunch table, but also for everyday glamour.

Buy now

Robert Welch bright cutlery set, 24-piece: £135, Robert Welch

This handsome cutlery set in a mirror-polished finish comes beautifully boxed, making it an ideal wedding gift – but it’s one you’ll want to covet for yourself. Crafted from the highest quality 18/10 stainless steel, this is cutlery for traditionalists looking to recreate the fine dining experience at home. The knives, forks, dessert spoons and teaspoons are weighted perfectly, and have been ergonomically designed for comfort. Best is the impressive 6cm fork tines made to successfully load up those peas.

Buy now

Nkuku Ista brushed gold cutlery set brushed gold, 16-piece: £140, Amara

Artisanal and luxurious in equal measure, this handcrafted cutlery set offered an instant talking point at our kitchen table. Discerning aesthetes will appreciate these metallic dining tools with their flat textured handles in a brushed gold finish, awarding them craft-driven and sculptural appeal. We loved the visual contrast between the aged gold and the bright and shiny stainless steel. This contrast continues in form, too, with shrewd design in the heavy-heeled knives and purposeful forks, juxtaposed with the raw-edged handles.

Buy now

ProCook grosvenor cutlery set, 16-piece: £49, ProCook

We loved this 16-piece set for its stylishly long and elegant lines as well as its smooth, tapered handles. With these tall utensils, we had no choice but to eat our dinner delicately. The cutlery – comprising four place settings of knife, fork, dessert spoon and teaspoon – is gently curved, making it comfortable to hold, on top of its obvious aesthetic appeal. Made from high quality 18/10 stainless steel, and with a super shiny mirror finish, its beauty is its simplicity.

Buy now

Alessi itsumo cutlery set, 24-piece: £89, Coggles

Great design should be in the everyday. This polished set takes its name from the Japanese for “always”, which alludes to designer Naoto Fukasawa’s love of simple things, well-crafted. Where most of the cutlery we tested triumphed in slimline elegance, this utilitarian series celebrates a wider silhouette with handles you can really get a handle on, as well as the simple shapes of the perfectly flat knives, and rounded rectangular spoons. Everyday but artfully design-led.

Buy now

Katie Alice vintage stainless steel cutlery set, 16-piece: £44.99, Katie Alice

For a playful dose of English whimsy at the dining table, this delightful vintage-inspired cutlery set boasts four different handle designs, each one as ornate as the next, to give the impression of a cobbled together collection you might have found in the antiques market. But of course, these 18/10 stainless steel utensils are positively gleaming in their newness and they match up in their own unique way with engraved floral detailing and elaborate shaping. We loved their Mad Hatter’s tea party appeal.

Buy now

Villeroy & Boch Boston cutlery set, 30-piece: £229, Villeroy & Boch

Modern luxury at its finest, this high-end 30-piece cutlery set boasts six place settings of five pieces each, including a miniature three-pronged pastry fork. Inside the clean contemporary lines is a harlequin-inspired diamond texture on the handles – the dimpled stainless steel catches the light beautifully to give a twinkling effect that’s perfect for a candlelit dinner. Wonderfully weighty and tangibly top quality, these really shined at our dinner party, awarding our table instant wow-factor.

Buy now

Cutipol Goa black & gold cutlery set, 24-piece: £352, Borough Kitchen

The handiwork of designer José Joaquim Ribeiro for Portuguese cutlery maker Cutipol, this striking set is the design lover’s choice – with a price tag to match. In matte black and gleaming gold, it’s no coincidence that the cutlery mimics an artist’s paintbrush with slender, tapered handles that dictate a delicate movement when eating. Best though is the original shaping of the utensils. We loved the perfectly circular spoons. These make for a design-led investment set, or a generous wedding gift.

Buy now

Studio iridescent stainless steel cutlery set, 16-piece: £19.99, Studio

At just under £20, our most affordable pick of the bunch is this eye-catching set of table tools from Studio. Iridescent homewares are having a moment, so it’s only right that cutlery should get in on the oil-slick inspired act. In their constant movement at the table (unlike a stationary vase), the colours change from purple to pink to green to gold, bringing a dynamic touch to lunchtimes. We’re happy to report the quality of these multicoloured utensils belie their price, offering great value for money.

Buy now

The verdict: Cutlery sets

Dibor’s 24 piece luxury gold cutlery set was an impressive mid-price find. The knives, forks and spoons are solid and sturdy in feel yet they offer an elegant profile with their slender handles and refined shaping. We loved the colour – a rich gold that brightens up the table without ever looking gaudy, making them the perfect choice for the festive season, but why wait? We’re all for everyday luxury.

description: Make any meal a special occasion with the best cutlery sets from Robert Welch, Dibor, Alessi and more
